archetypes.name: Hero's Journey
examples: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone

acts.name: Setup
acts.goal: Show the hero’s ordinary world, trigger the call to adventure, and force a commitment to change.

chapters.goal: Establish protagonist, their want/need, flaw, and everyday life.
Inciting incident disrupts normal; stakes and opposition are revealed.
Hero commits; crosses the threshold into a new world or path.

acts.name: Confrontation
acts.goal: Test the hero through escalating trials that expose weaknesses and force growth.

chapters.goal: Early trials teach the rules; small win/small loss.
Meet allies and enemies; define the antagonist force.
Midpoint: revelation or high-stakes choice changes the plan.
Consequences escalate; hero’s flaw costs them something important.
‘All is lost’: major setback separates hero from support or hope.

acts.name: Resolution
acts.goal: Face the final test and resolve internal/external conflicts; return transformed.

chapters.goal: Climax: hero confronts the antagonist using lessons learned.
External conflict resolves; internal arc pays off.
Return to a new normal; show lasting change and loose-end closure.

archetypes.name: Quest
examples: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade

acts.name: The Mission Begins
acts.goal: Define the objective, why it matters, and who’s going along.

chapters.goal: State the quest objective (what, why, stakes if failed).
Assemble allies and tools; set roles and tensions.
Cross into hostile territory; first barrier or guardian.

acts.name: The Journey & Obstacles
acts.goal: Test endurance, faith, and relationships through escalating trials.

chapters.goal: Obstacle gauntlet #1; teamwork forged by necessity.
Detour or betrayal creates mistrust and resource loss.
Midpoint ordeal: hardest terrain/guardian; heavy cost paid.
Insight: true nature/location of the prize reframes the quest.
Approach: final leg under pursuit or deadline pressure.

acts.name: The Prize and Return
acts.goal: Earn or lose the prize and return changed, with consequences.

chapters.goal: Final trial: test of worthiness at the destination.
Reward and cost: obtain (or fail) and pay the price.
Return/homecoming and impact on community.

acts.name: The Fall or Stagnation
acts.goal: Reveal the protagonist’s broken state and why change is needed.

chapters.goal: Show the flawed normal: vice, cynicism, or numbness.
Consequences harm others/work; raise moral stakes.
Catalyst person/event plants the seed of change.

acts.name: The Struggle for Renewal
acts.goal: Resist, fail, and confront the truth leading to symbolic death.

chapters.goal: Resistance: rationalize the status quo; avoid accountability.
Failed attempt to improve using old patterns.
Mid-crash: humiliation, loss, or exposure of the flaw.
Moment of truth: admit fault; glimpse better self.
Symbolic death: surrender old identity or belief.

acts.name: The Renewal
acts.goal: Recommit to new values and repair what was broken.

chapters.goal: Rebirth in action: choose new behavior under pressure.
Make amends; repair relationships or systems harmed.
Integration: stable new self and ripple effects on the world.

acts.name: The Threat Emerges
acts.goal: Introduce the monster/evil and the stakes for the community.

chapters.goal: Show peaceful community and hero’s limits/capabilities.
Reveal evidence and scale of the threat.
Hero pledges to fight; secures permission/resources.

acts.name: The Battle Build-up
acts.goal: Prepare, clash, suffer loss, and discover the key weakness.

chapters.goal: Train/arm; gather intel and specialized tools.
First encounter; underestimation leads to casualties.
Retreat and regroup; leadership crisis tests resolve.
Discover the monster’s weakness or true form.
Formulate risky plan that exploits the weakness.

acts.name: The Final Battle
acts.goal: Defeat or be devoured; show the cost and aftermath.

chapters.goal: Climactic confrontation; execute the gambit.
Sacrifice is made to secure victory.
Aftermath: community rebuilt; vigilance/theme stated.

archetypes.name: Voyage & Return
examples: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe

acts.name: Departure
acts.goal: Leave the ordinary world and enter a strange realm.

chapters.goal: Ground the reader in ordinary life and the protagonist’s longing.
Cross a portal/accident into the strange world.
Orientation: first awe; begin learning the new rules.

acts.name: The Strange World
acts.goal: Adaptation and misadventure culminate in the need to escape.

chapters.goal: Explore with a guide; pass early tests of adaptation.
Cultural clash/error brings consequences and enemies.
False victory: temporary belonging or success.
Betrayal/reversal reveals true danger; desire to go home spikes.
Escape attempt triggers chase/maze; toll must be paid.

acts.name: Return and Integration
acts.goal: Return home changed and apply lessons to the original world.

chapters.goal: Return through portal or rescue from the strange world.
Reconciliation: translate insight to old relationships/problems.
New equilibrium: perspective and status permanently changed.

archetypes.name: Mystery
examples: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo

acts.name: The Case Opens
acts.goal: Introduce the sleuth, the world, and the central puzzle/crime.

chapters.goal: Establish investigator, setting, tone, and method.
Inciting crime/puzzle; define stakes and suspects.
Commitment: accept the case and initial theory.

acts.name: Investigation & Complications
acts.goal: Follow clues through red herrings and danger to a dead end.

chapters.goal: Gather obvious clues; interview the circle.
Red herrings and false suspects multiply.
Midpoint twist: paradigm shift in motive/timeline/alibi.
Pressure rises; suspect strikes back; sleuth endangered.
Setback: theory collapses; ally imperiled or evidence tainted.

acts.name: Revelation & Resolution
acts.goal: Reframe the evidence, expose the culprit, and settle the moral ledger.

chapters.goal: Breakthrough: reinterpret a key clue; set a trap.
Reveal: unmask culprit; lay out motive and proof.
Aftermath: justice served or ambiguity acknowledged.

archetypes.name: Rebellion
examples: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story

acts.name: Seeds of Dissent
acts.goal: Show the oppressive system and spark the protagonist’s defiance.

chapters.goal: Everyday oppression; protagonist’s private doubts and line they won’t cross.
Triggering injustice harms protagonist or loved one; stakes personalize.
Public break: commit to dissent with a first bold act.

acts.name: Rising Resistance
acts.goal: Build the movement, survive crackdown, and endure betrayal.

chapters.goal: Recruit and organize: symbols, cells, and message.
First win sparks hope and harsher regime response.
Crackdown: surveillance, arrests; moral compromises tempt.
Betrayal/infiltration fractures trust; plans exposed.
Low point: movement scattered; leader questioned or captured.

acts.name: Revolution and Outcome
acts.goal: Strike decisively and confront the cost; establish the new order or cautionary ending.

chapters.goal: Coordinated uprising or surgical strike; decisive gambit.
Outcome: regime falls, hero dies, or compromise; costs tallied.
Aftermath: new order’s first steps or warning of cycles repeating.
